metadata.title: What your terminal colors reveal about your personality | by Ari Joury, PhD | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: What your terminal colors reveal about your personality
metadata.description: When used right, colors increase speed and readability. But above all, they’re a mirror of the personality of a programmer. Some people express themselves more through colors than others — which…

all_paragraphs: Coding is an art. So colors are invariably part of the deal!
When used right, colors increase speed and readability. But above all, they’re a mirror of the personality of a programmer.

Some people express themselves more through colors than others — which already says a lot about their egos. Some people choose to customize their background, others prefer to let the text look like a heap of M&M’s. Others do both.
And every aspect tells a story about who you are as a programmer, and how you feel in daily life.

How you color your background unveils your comfort zone. Your terminal background is what you look at every day, whether you’re coding or not. Therefore, how you keep your background says a lot about how you feel on a daily basis.
Elegance comes in black. You’re laid-back, stylish, and you have that certain je-ne-sais-quoi, whether you’re coding or not.

Your colleagues think that you’re an over-achiever. They think of you almost as a celebrity, despite your measly 30 followers on Twitter. You’re neither a celebrity nor an over-achiever, but you know how to market yourself.
When you talk, you talk loudly. After all, why talk if nobody hears you?
You’re someone who enjoys life to the full.
You live. You love. You indulge. But never to a decadent extent.
You’re an artist on the tightrope between discipline and indulgence. Your terminal reflects just that.
You don’t think of yourself as disorganized. You just admire the level of organization that others have.
When you wake up, you have no idea what the day ahead is going to bring. You hate planning because that throws you out of your rhythm.

Every surface in your office is cluttered with folders, notes, and a few gifts from last Christmas. You’ve forgotten where your favorite coffee cup went; it’s probably hidden somewhere behind a few books.

Speaking of coffee — ah, caffeine! Your holy grail and the one and only secret to your productivity. No matter that it makes you even more jittery than you are already. Come grab a coffee and start coding!
This is for the users of every shade of gray. You can’t decide between black and white. You wouldn’t want a color because that would be too much distraction.
You like to keep things functional: You chose a light gray because white is too bright for you. Or you chose a dark grey because black is — well — too black for you.
You’re indecisive but not inefficient. You get your work done, but don’t speak loudly about it. In meetings, you usually sit in the corner and never speak unless you’re asked to.

You like to keep private things private and business things professional. You don’t like to speak loudly because that would be a waste of energy. You don’t have any political views because that would be controversial. And, above all, you don’t like to have people’s attention.
You have a gray terminal? You’re a gray mouse in every sense.
You’re bored with black, white and gray. You want your terminal in your favorite color, or at least a color that stimulates your attention.
You like to express yourself in every sense. Your variable names in your code are one of a kind, your style of clothing is unmistakably you. You have an affinity for art, music and comedy.
You’re a rarity among programmers. You always stand out in a crowd. And you enjoy that.
You use your terminal color to express who you are.
Your terminal is red? You’re an amazing lover.
Yellow? You’re like a ray of sunshine.
Blue? You love technical things, and the sky, and the sea…
Purple? You’re a weirdo in disguise. People aren’t even aware of all the crazy thoughts in your head!
You’ve tried monochrome backgrounds but you have gotten bored rather quickly. You prefer to use a picture of your favorite galaxy, or of your first teddybear, or of your mom…
People call you eccentric, but in reality you’re just a big kid. Curiosity is what drives you. Programming is your vocation because it’s about learning new things all the time.
You have a huge and uncontrollable affinity to everything that’s sweet and colorful. Your concentration span is that of a three-year-old; you get waylead by every distraction.
Still, you deliver consistently at work. Your never-ending supply of ideas compensates for your shortness of attention.
Text inspires action. It is the thing that comes and goes on your screen. Which text colors you use reflects what you’re driven by.
Which, in turn, says a lot about who you are.
You don’t like your text looking like a bag of M&M’s. You’d rather stick to a good old-fashioned black, white or gray. That’s just how much you love your craft.

You’re committed in everything. That person who’s always on time, always gives 150%, and always has something useful to say — that’s you. Your output is consistent and at a high level. When you say yes, you mean it.

Some people might call you uppity. You always come in the office with a beaming smile and have some comment about what somebody is doing. More often than not, that can be insulting — because your ideas are wrong and out of context. You have a strong tendency to show everyone you know better.
But you don’t know better. You just love your work.
Most systems come with a default color scheme. Despite having coded for the last ten years or so, you haven’t changed that scheme. Never touch a running system!
You can work with everything and anything. Flexibility is your second name.

Got a spontaneous meeting in ten minutes? Quickly jam up some slides. Got to work with a totally different software? Oh yeah, you love changes! Your cat is sick? No problem, you’ll do home office today.

The downside is that people perceive you as a bit unreliable. You’re not that person that shows up to the office at the same time each day — on some days, your cat is sick. And people never know what expect when you deliver results — it depends what environment it’s written in, right?
You’ve tried to get on with the default color scheme, but you just found it clunky and inefficient. So you invested a half-day or so to find the perfect colors for your text.
People who walk past your laptop find your scheme quite eye-catching. But they have no idea what each color really means. Only you know that.

Your colors are for you and only you. In the same way, your life belongs only to you. You’re extremely reserved and keep things to yourself. You learn a lot, but you can’t be bothered to share your knowledge with others. You don’t like to talk in meetings — but when you do, your input is brilliant.
You’re extremely smart, but sometimes you’d be better off sharing your wisdom. Yup, even your color scheme!
Of course you’ve customized the colors in your terminal. After all, how should anyone deal with those crappy default colors?

The capacity of your brain is your most precious resource. You don’t like to waste any thoughts on the use of different colors in different environments. Which is why you haven’t only customized your shell — you’ve customized your text editor in the same way!
You’re consistent at work and always deliver high-level results. You attribute that to the fact that you don’t lose time on little things like colors.
That’s your approach to efficiency: Remove the clutter, and the rest will go by itself. And obviously it works!
Consistency is key, also in personalities — but contradictions are much more interesting!
In this story, we have reviewed five types of background colors and four types of text. If we allow every combination, we arrive at twenty different types of terminal colors.
Some of the personality traits that are revealed in the background might also be reflected in the text. Others may be downright contradictory.
And aren’t all humans walking contradictions? While the consistent types do occur a lot more often, it’s the contradictory ones that are intriguing.
Elaborating on each contradictory type would blast the scope of this story. But maybe you’re a contradictory type yourself? How do you explain your consistencies and your contradictions?
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Lost in my thoughts, mostly about tech. https://arijoury.medium.com/membership
